BMI British Midland, the UK's second-largest airline by passenger volumes, suffered a 26 per cent fall in pre-tax profits last year from GBP11.1m ($15.8m) to GBP8.2m.
Profits declined despite a 17 per cent increase in turnover to GBP739m as the company invested heavily to prepare for the launch of its first scheduled long-haul services to the US.
The company also invested to reshape its European short-haul network in a joint venture with Lufthansa and SAS Scandinavian Airlines.
BMI starts direct services from Manchester to Washington DC six times a week from Saturday and daily services to Chicago from June 8.
It charged GBP4m against profits for the investment in the transatlantic services. There was a further GBP2m for accelerated depreciation as a result of an upgrading of the airline's booking and reservation systems to bring it into line with systems used by other carriers in the Star alliance, which BMI joined last year.
Passenger volumes increased by 8.4 per cent to 7.1m as the airline benefited from the chaos in the UK rail network last year.
Capacity was increased by just 4.5 per cent and as a result the airline's load factor - the share of available seats sold - rose from 61.6 to 64 per cent.
Sir Michael Bishop, chairman, said 2001 had "started in a promising manner".
Turnover rose 12 per cent in the first quarter while yields or average fare levels rose 17 per cent, partly as a result of weakening price competition from the low-cost carriers, which had raised fares in the first quarter on UK domestic routes.
"The era of very low pricing has passed its peak," Sir Michael said. Some fares were close to those of the full service airlines. "Passengers can now choose between no frills and full service at prices that are not very different," he said.
Karl-Ludwig Kley, Lufthansa chief financial officer, has been appointed to the BMI board. Lufthansa and SAS both hold 20 per cent stakes in BMI.
The long-haul services from Manchester to the US are being launched in a code-sharing arrangement with United Airlines. This will allow BMI to offer its customers flights with its own code to a further 20 US destinations.
The airline is also campaigning hard to break into the lucrative market from Heathrow to the US.
